chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of complications of prostate cancer and adverse effects of treatments
chapter.summary: Covers how men with prostate cancer are followed up, what complications and adverse effects of treatment may need to be recognized or managed in primary care, the approach to palliative care, and advice on information resources and support groups for men with complications or adverse effects.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 30 years onwards (Male).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I follow up and monitor men with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Men with prostate cancer should be followed up in primary care in line with locally agreed protocols.
  • For all men, review and manage:
    • Complications of the disease, including pain, lower urinary tract symptoms, and symptoms of spinal cord compression.
    • Adverse effects from treatment, including sexual dysfunction and urinary incontinence.
      • Adverse effects of androgen withdrawal include change in body shape and weight gain, tiredness, hot flushes, loss of libido, erectile dysfunction, gynaecomastia, and loss of bone density.
    • Quality of life.
  • For men who are being managed with:
    • Watchful waiting — prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels should be measured at least once a year.
      • Digital rectal examination (DRE) is not recommended on a routine basis while the PSA level remains at baseline values.
    • Active surveillance, see Table 1 Protocol for active surveillance, in the section on active surveillance. 
    • Radical treatment — PSA levels should be measured no earlier than 6 weeks after treatment, then at least every 6 months for 2 years, and once a year thereafter.
      • After at least two years, follow-up can be carried out by telephone or secure electronic communications to men with a stable PSA level who have had no significant treatment complications.
  • If biochemical relapse (rising PSA level) occurs, an estimate of PSA doubling time should be calculated based on a minimum of 3 measurements over at least 6 months.
  • Refer men with evidence of significant disease progression (rapidly rising PSA level or bone pain) to a urological cancer specialist.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Prostate cancer: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2014].

subChapters.fullItemName: Adverse effects of hormonal therapies including orchidectomy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage adverse effects of hormonal therapies, including orchidectomy, in men with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Hot flushes
    • Offer medroxyprogesterone acetate 20 mg per day, initially for a period of 10 weeks. 
      • Evaluate the effect at the end of this treatment period.
    • Consider cyproterone acetate 50 mg twice a day for 4 weeks if medroxyprogesterone is not effective, or not tolerated.
    • Explain that there is no strong evidence to support the use of complementary therapies to treat hot flushes.
  • Fatigue
    • Offer men who are starting or taking androgen deprivation therapy supervised resistance and aerobic exercise at least twice a week for 12 weeks to reduce fatigue and improve quality of life.
  • Osteoporosis
    • Do not routinely offer bisphosphonates to prevent osteoporosis in men taking androgen deprivation therapy.
    • Consider assessing the fracture risk in men taking androgen deprivation therapy. For more information, see the section on assessing a person for fragility fracture risk in the CKS topic on Osteoporosis - prevention of fragility fractures.
      • Offer bisphosphonates to men who have osteoporosis.
      • Consider denosumab for men in whom bisphosphonates are contraindicated, or not tolerated. 
  • Gynaecomastia
    • For men starting long-term bicalutamide monotherapy (longer than 6 months), offer referral to a specialist for prophylactic radiotherapy to both breast buds within the first month of treatment. 
    • If radiotherapy is unsuccessful, consider tamoxifen weekly.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Prostate cancer: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage palliative care and pain in a man with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • For information on palliative care, and the management of cancer pain, see the CKS topics on Palliative care - general issues, and Palliative cancer care - pain.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage radiation-induced enteropathy in men with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ensure that men with signs or symptoms of radiation-induced enteropathy are offered care from a healthcare team with expertise in radiation-induced enteropathy.
    • Symptoms may include diarrhoea, faecal urgency, steatorrhoea or rectal pain.
  • Specialist assessment is likely to involve sigmoidoscopy to ascertain the nature of the radiation injury and exclude such conditions as inflammatory bowel disease and cancer of the large bowel.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Prostate cancer: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2014] and expert opinion in a narrative review Radiation-induced small bowel disease: latest developments and clinical guidance [Stacey, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage sexual dysfunction in men with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Tell men (and, if they wish, their partner), before starting androgen deprivation therapy that it may cause a loss of libido and possible sexual function.
    • Advise men about the possible loss of ejaculation and fertility associated with therapy, and offer sperm storage.
  • Ensure men have access to a sexual health specialist. 
    • Consider referring men (and their partner) for psychosexual counselling.
  • Offer a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor, such as sildenafil, tadalafil, or vardenafil, to men who experience loss of erectile function. 
    • If PDE-5 inhibitors are ineffective or contraindicated, offer a choice of:
      • Intraurethral inserts.
      • Penile injections.
      • Penile prostheses.
      • Vacuum devices.
  • For more information, see the CKS topic on Erectile dysfunction.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Prostate cancer: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected spinal cord compression in men with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Suspected spinal cord compression is a medical emergency. It must be diagnosed and treated before there is significant neurological compromise.
  • For more information, see the Scenario: Spinal cord compression in the CKS topic on Palliative cancer care - pain.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Metastatic spinal cord compression in adults: risk assessment, diagnosis and management [NICE, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage urinary incontinence or retention in men with prostate cancer?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Warn men undergoing radical treatment for prostate cancer of the likely effects of the treatment on their urinary function.
    • Offer men experiencing urinary symptoms before treatment a urological assessment. 
  • Ensure men with troublesome urinary symptoms after treatment have access to specialist continence services for assessment, diagnosis and conservative treatment. 
    • Management options coping strategies, pelvic floor muscle re-education, bladder retraining or medicines. 
  • Refer men with intractable urinary incontinence to a specialist surgeon for consideration of an artificial urinary sphincter.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Prostate cancer: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2014].
